title: How to improve my singing without vocal lessons - Quora

response.answer_text: The real question is: why would you want to? Singing lessons to improve your ability? Understanding your instrument, how to control it, how to make it work better? Wouldn’t you want to learn something as important as that? I’m amazed at how many people there are who believe that being good is not as impressive as being good without doing any work. If singing was something that I wanted to do (which it is), and wanted to do well (ditto), and I wanted to make a career out of singing and performing (yeah, that too), and I realized that I was not making progress on my own (oh hell yeah, been there), I would do whatever I could, whatever it took to become ‘better at singing’, as you say. In fact, just asking this question, and receiving these answers, you are now unable to say that you trained your singing without any help. The mini-lessons you’ve received - solfege, learn by rote, record yourself to develop an objective ear - could point you in the right direction and eventually help you realize that an organized plan might be what you need. It seems as though your question to Quora could’ve read: “Could you please help me to be a better singer, so I can say that nobody helped me?” Many singers develop on their own, but they all reach a point when they need advice or guidance to proceed further. You sing well; what next? you sing in church, at school, on street corners, in your garage - then what? find a band? find a DJ? become a DJ? how? sing at school dances, clubs, concert halls? how? record a video, a demo? how? what will you sing? how will you find songs? will you write your own? how? will you find a writing/ recording/ producing partner/team? HOW? No one - no one - goes from point zero to superstardom with absolutely no help. Get used to admitting that you don’t know it all, and ask for help. Ask early, because help costs a lot less sooner than later…

The value of lessons is in the personal guidance and feedback you will receive. Without lessons of any kind, you will need to start with good vocal health, excellent hearing and be very well book read on the science of the voice and the physics of making sound, vocal technique and pedagogy specific to the vocal instrument for the genre(s) you want to sing, as the terminology can differ between classical and popular styles, and there is a lot of information out there. You will also need some luck in determining the correct information, as there is a lot of incorrect technique and advice floating around on the Internet, including YouTube. If you don’t know which teachers to follow for both information and quality demonstration, you might not be able to tell which great sounding singing is healthy and which is not, because there is a lot of great sounding singing to the untrained ear, but a trained singer knows what is healthy. They can feel it in their own voice. However, a good teacher can also hear it in others’ voices. That is expertise that you won’t have without lessons. Because singing lessons can be very cost-prohibitive, I would recommend saving your money for a really good teacher. Get a few in-person lessons when they can squeeze you into their schedule. If you can do a month or two of weekly lessons and you practice faithfully, that should get you started, and then you can request longer gaps for lessons. With infrequent lessons, you won’t progress as quickly, and some teachers don’t have the bandwidth to handle inconsistent student schedules, but if you are flexible and will take whatever timeslot you can get, perhaps they can contact you when they have an opening and you can at least get evaluated periodically to see if you have anything specific that needs work. Of course, regular lessons are really preferred to continue progress, but once you have reached a certain point and can correct your own vocal issues for the most part, you can have less frequent lessons and still manage to maintain slight progress, or at least not reintroducing old habits, if you continue regular practice. In the meantime, don’t do things that do obvious damage to the voice. Don’t smoke, don’t yell, get enough sleep and fluids, and avoid anything that feels like strain. Of course you may not know what strain and tension are hiding in your voice without lessons, but at least avoid the obvious. Nothing should hurt, and while some minor fatigue may be normal since you are training muscles, it shouldn’t go beyond that. If you’re tired vocally, rest and try again when it is better. Listen to examples in YouTube of singers and teachers demonstrating the differences between supported, resonant tone, and strained, pushed notes. There’s a lot to be learned there, but without a teacher’s support, there is no sure way to prevent building poor habits on your own. If you have friends who are voice students who can hear you live, they may be able to give you some feedback. Even if they are not qualified to teach, but there is no guarantee that they have been trained correctly, either, which is why they are students and not teachers. There are also teachers that weren’t correctly trained that you may improve with but only to a limited point. If you’re not trained, you may not know the difference. Don’t rule out lessons, if you really want to sing, even for yourself. Save up and prioritize as you can. Make friends who sing, so you can get started with basic pitch matching and rhythm. Learn to keep your voice even. Focus on dynamics. Do a lot of listening to high quality vocals to train your ears, and try to be very aware when you are vocalizing or singing, or even speaking, so you can build your ability to sense vocal changes. Those who do take lessons will take months or years to learn these things with guidance, in small doses. You may be behind them if you can’t take lessons, but that doesn’t mean you can’t eventually get there if you can get lessons later in life. In the meantime, study well and then practice carefully. I have made recommendations in other posts for singing teachers that I have seen in YouTube who have good teaching and demonstrative skills, and some websites that are very informational and accurate. I’ll include them again here by name, and you can look them up or check other singing related questions on Quora, starting with the Topic FAQ. Justin Stoney, New York Vocal Coaching / Voice Lessons to the WorldKimberley Smith, Inspired to SingKaryn O’Connor, Singwise There are others who are good as far as accuracy and demonstration, but these are my preferred online references, as they are clear, concise, personable, and excellent at demonstration as well.

Singing isn't a privilege given to a choose few. Anyone that can speak can sing due to the fact singing is continued speech, supported by air. Learn How To Sing better http://trckapp.com/4fzp92r4 But for the ones who can not afford to study with a private trainer and are not capable of sign up for a making a song elegance at school, I'm providing a number of the important steps wished to learn how to sing. Follow these steps carefully and practice day by day to accurate gift vocal weaknesses and take your voice to the subsequent level. As you exercise the vocal techniques outlined, pay attention and really focus on how the sound "feels." This might be a more correct barometer of how properly you are getting to know to sing than to pay attention for the proper sound. You can not pay attention your proper sound so that you ought to learn how to "sense" with your body what accurate making a song is. Learn how to improve your singing without vocal lessons here http://trckapp.com/4fzp92r4 Tip: Concentration is critical as you practice matching a pitch. Listen! Really cognizance on the sound of your voice. A commonplace motive for failure to sing on key is genuinely a lack of concentration. Do now not anticipate immediate results. Avoid excessive expectations and any self-grievance or judgment. This will only deter your progress. Remember to use right breath support. One motive of making a song a note or phrase 'flat' is loss of energy which comes from inadequate air upon inhalation. So before you sing that first notice be sure to 'tank up" with lots of air completed from the diaphragm. (Belly Breathing.) And now you are equipped to learn the secret to top making a song. You can pay attention it inside the sound of your voice and feel it on your throat whilst it happens. The muscles aggravating and your vocal tone sounds pinched and shrill. You’re straining and in case your voice doesn’t crack, you could remember your self lucky. Perhaps you handiest experience strain when singing positive songs. You might think it’s due to the fact you weren’t born to sing in positive keys or you just have a certainly low voice or the song is incorrect for you (despite the fact that you like it). Sure, you can lower the key or certainly no longer encompass certain songs in your repertoire. However, there may be a hidden reason why you pressure whilst singing and because you don’t recognise what it is, you need to blame it on other things. Putting your interest on things that are not the real purpose, keeps the answer illusive and unobtainable. So, are you prepared for the unveiling of the responsible party? Click here http://trckapp.com/4fzp92r4 Singing after proper vocal muscle improvement through limbering and strengthening physical games is a completely different enjoy and one that is free of stress. It sounds well on its way. I'd be careful not to breathe in the middle of a phrase, which I think I heard you do. Also, try it with an accompaniment for better sense of the harmonies. The intonation is mostly where it needs to be, but not quite. I wrote this next bit before listening to your clip, but this is the advice I would give for someone who wanted to do something more in the classical vein, but it probably still applies; I once heard Helmut Lotti say pretty much the same to describe how he takes care of his voice. Learn to read music if you don't already. Also, if you can play keyboard, so much the better, because it will help you learn songs. Try to have access to one.Take proper care of yourself: get enough sleep, drink lots of water, keep alcohol to a minimum, and don't smoke.Facebook can actually be a great source of information. It has groups that discuss singing technique.Keep yourself physically fit. Also, keep stress to a minimum. A good music teacher will offer end up being part therapist, so the less you need one of those as well, the better. And stay in touch with your emotions.Have good posture, preferably at most times so you don't have to think about that aspect of it too havrd while you singing.If you don't already have one, get a public library card. The library night have books on the subject that you can borrow. (I actually have a copy of Singing for Dummies, and it's not bad.) And they might also have DVDs you can watch, e-books you can borrow, etcThere are also helpful YouTube videos. Some are lessons, but there are also masterclass where singers give what that think are they're just polished performances and more famous and experienced singers tear their singing apart and put it before together in new and wondrous ways.There are also magazines that discuss vocal technique, and some of them have websites. One it my favorites was Voice Council, but they've stopped publication, but I believe they still have an archive up.If you've read up on the subject and watched video, you will have come across various warmups. Have a selection of those that you do every day, preferably not first thing in the morning.When working on rep, make audio and video recordings. The audio will be merciless but it will let you hear what you need to work on. The video will show you what you're doing. If you make funny movements that affect your sound, video will allow you to correct them.A former teacher once ordered the following advice on vocal technique in a nutshell: from the shoulders down, genius! From the shoulders up, dummy! In other words, everything happening in the head it because should feel effortless. Any effort should be happening below the shoulders. And if you hurt anywhere, for heaven's sake, stop and rest. If that doesn't work to make it stop hurting, stop for the day.My personal favorite warmup is to sing overtones on a fundamental pitch in my middle register, which helps me concentrate my tone. FWIW. Something like this: Good luck!

There are free online tutorials, - but using them is nothing like a real, live teacher who can respond to your sound and habits. So on your limited budget the best thing is to find the best teacher you can, and take a few lessons, or lessons “few and far between,” as you can afford it. There’s no substitute for a live teacher. Also, there is a lot of print material. Probably the best book on singing, if you’re academically oriented, is Richard Miller’s The Structure of Singing. Check it out from your local library; it’s expensive. Use Interlibrary Loan if necessary. Again, Get an experienced teacher who has academic credentials. Until then, see the practice ideas below. Good luck! ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ ABCs of Singing There’s an easy way to think about voice culture: the ABCs of Singing. The same things apply to the speaking voice. A is for Alignment. For singing, stand with feet a few cm. apart, NOT exactly parallel, with weight slightly forward on the balls of the feet. Feel a sense of energy in your feet and legs. Keep knees flexible, not tight. Raise your hands far, far above your head, and then allow them to descend and rest easily at your sides. Let your back be straight. Imagine there is a silver thread from the base of your spine out the top of your head that allows your body to float up, up, up. Allow the ribs to expand like an opening umbrella. It is never static or tight, but flexible and dynamic. As you practice, come back to these points, and refresh your alignment/posture. B is for Breathing. Exercise: “Breathe through a straw,” inhale through puckered lips. Immediately hiss out LOUDLY, with great energy from the middle of the body (abdominal area). Feel how this increases energy in the breath. Maintain alignment - don’t allow the upper body to collapse as you exhale. Return to this exercise a few times as you practice. As you sing, breathe LOW in the body, and imagine you have a tire inner tube around your middle; fill it up and lean into it. Always think “up.” C is for Coordination. Importantly, as you go higher, let the voice get lighter and brighter - don’t use a lot of pressure. But, allow the ribs to rise a little, and allow the energy from the middle of the body to increase a little. Don’t yell or scream - instead, slightly increase breath energy and expand your posture to make the sound a little higher or louder. Exercise: easily repeat one note with a breath between then sustain and crescendo diminuendo - get louder and softer [ a, a, a, a———- ] . Repeat the exercise on different vowels and higher note, several times. As you go higher, let the voice feel lighter and brighter.This is a very basic start. To really improve your singing voice, get a teacher with academic credentials in voice teaching.

This is not to devalue vocal coaches (great ones can bring out your best), but I got most of my skills through repetition and practice and am mostly self-taught. I do sing full-time (jazz mostly, between restaurants and events. I’ll never be famous, but I do think I will work as long as I can). I did have some lessons in college as a theater major, but I never thought I would be a singer because of my looks. It wasn’t till someone pointed out how certain music worked with my voice and hired me that I found I could make money as a jazz singer. I started out busking and worked my way to a place of financial security… kind of. You never know with this job, but I’m seven years in and have not had a “real” job in all that time. I had always listened to certain artists and some of their style rubbed off, though not their exact phrasing, but I committed to jazz and listened to as many great women as I could, played around with what I liked about their interpretation, what I might do differently. I think a lot of it was instinct or just a history of growing up with them in my ears, but a lot of it was just playing with it, song-by-song, taking each and trying to see it as a something I wanted to communicate the meaning of. So, whatever genre you want to sing in, find the best straight up, disciplined vocalists in that genre (just speaking as a woman, I see the best as Ella Fitzgerald for Jazz vocals, Edith Piaf for raw emotion, Anne Wilson for Rock, Anita Baker for Soul, I could go on forever as there are so many greats) and listen to what the way they caress a note or a phrase and play with your own interpretation

I have experience with this! I used to suck at singing, and I didn’t really know that I sucked until I tried out for a choir and I didn’t make it. My heart was broken. However I was given the opportunity to try out at a later point. I decided that I would try out again, and that I would make it. Now what I did was I practiced! I was singing all the time. And by all the time I mean I was told to shut up frequently. I would say the number one thing is to just sing, and to try and be aware of how you sound. For me this was pressing down on one ear, because it helped me hear myself. I still do that when I’m a little uncertain of a note. Another way is to record yourself, and listen. That way you can pinpoint what sounds wrong and try to fix it. Number two, is learn how to correctly sing vowels, because that can really change how you sound. Number three, is learn how to correctly breathe. That will also do wonders for you! You don’t want to breath shallow breathes ( you can tell if they’re shallow by if your chest is rising and falling), take deep breathes that can support you as you sing. You can tell if you’re doing this by if your stomach is inflating with your breathes. Number four, correct singing posture. Just trust me on this, look it up they can probably explain it better then me. Number five, learn music theory and how to sightread sheet music. It really just helps. Anyways hope this helped! Oh and by the way when I tried out for the choir I made it!

I have answered this sort of question endless times in my other answers related to singing: Rather than try to mis-merge questions, I will just recommend that you read the other answers. The main point to remember is that you can learn a limited amount of basic breathing technique, vocal pedagogy, and lots about the science of the voice, without a teacher: What a teacher will bring you is their trained ears and ability to help you identify and become aware of what you are doing with your voice: A lot of times there are issues because you are trying too hard: The best singing comes without strain, without pushing, without clenching: It's a matter of many vocal coordinations, and only some of that can be learned by mimicking; moreover, you can build incorrect and poor vocal habits that will cause your formal singing training to have to take longer to undo. Learn the breathing and basics of vocal pedagogy and science behind the voice: Watch recommended videos from proven vocal coaches. The only one I've found that matches my teacher's training is Justin Stoney: My teacher is a mentor for an international organization who does lectures and training for other vocal teachers, and she is still open to learning and improving even further from other mentors and vocal coaches: She trains also, but with someone else's superpower ears. Aim for breathing technique, steady airflow, and correct posture, relaxing the body, head, neck, shoulders, know how to relax your larynx, and know how to shape your tongue and lips: You will need to be able to reasonably match pitch, but accurate pitch and vibrato will come with correct singing technique: You should never try to force anything with singing: If you're supporting your voice, it will come up properly: Most issues with singing are corrected with proper technique and regular practice of that proper technique: If you are serious about singing, figure out how you can get a really good coach: If you can't afford regular lessons, at least see if you can pay for a couple of lessons so they can evaluate you, and give you a starting point: From there you can practice on your own with that knowledge and go back after some time, to see what you can do better next: The difficulty there is that it depends on where you are at vocally: It takes a lot of time to become aware of certain things, if you are not with a teacher and you can't identify it right away, or can't remember the sensation after the lesson is over, you may be in trouble: Be extra focused, make sure the lesson is professionally recorded, and practice with that lesson: Listen to the differences that the teacher indicates, and correlate that with your bodily sensations: You have to become on heightened alert, and train your ears, your muscles, and your memory. Edited to add another vocal coach that seems to provide good, explanatory lessons that seems correct so far as I have seen: Kimberley Smith on This answer is from: How Can I Improve Singing Without A Vocal Coach? If you’re trying to really make something out of your voice (whether for fun or to make a living) there’s a difference in learning properly and getting random tips scattered around the internet. That difference is generally friends and family smiling faintly and people actually WANTING to hear you sing. If you haven’t seen it already LearnToSingTV is giving away a full free audio book which will help take your singing from A to Z. Everything you need in one course: The ONE THING That will Improve Your Singing Immediately (Full Free Audiobook Download)

Hi! I am a 25 years old singer and I have had singing lessons since I was 15, so I have a few things to share that might be helpful to you: keep practicing! do it anywhere, all the time.before you start singing, do some stretches and yawns.be kind to yourself, don't push it too hardif it hurts, you’re doing something wrongif you feel too much pressure in your throat, it’s wrong.if it makes you feel tired, vocally, you’re doing something wrong.do breathing exercisesdo tongue exercises, like licking you teeth ten times from side to side, then the other side, etc…put your whole body into it, but relax your neck, lips e tongue as much as you can.listen! if you're flat or out of tune it’s because you’re not listening in your head before you sing. don’t rush it, give it time so you know exactly what note or melody to sing.listen! you know if you like what you're doing by listening to yourself. you can record yourself, just try to not be so judgmental. If it was someone else, someone you like a lot, what would you say to that person to make their singing better?listen to singers that you like, specially those who can still sing after old age. It means they have technique and are not just shouting or being well edited after.pay attention to the sound of your voice while you talk. That’s more or less how your voice should sound when you sing. Although imitating other singers can work sometimes, don't try to be someone you're not. Be the best version of yourself, instead of being a worse version of someone else.you can always watch masterclasses from great people at youtube.singing must feel good, it’s like massaging you're interior with music. If it makes you feel bad about yourself or bad in anyway, you're doing it wrong.Keep singing, don't give up! Best wishes.

Learn to play a guitar, piano or another instrument to accompany your singing. An well tuned instrument when played will serve as a guide for your ear and will allow you to home in on notes more accurately. You will also be able to extend your range by playing notes just above (or below it) and allowing your voice to start getting used to those registers. Guitar and piano are simple instruments and you don't need lessons or a lot of practice to get them to usable level where you can enjoy improving your singing. Watch few videos on how to play simple chords and chord progressions and have fun. Of course, if you dislike playing an instrument there's no value in forcing it. Maybe finding somebody who would accompany you is an option. Somebody who's inclined to learn piano or guitar perhaps. When it comes to piano (or guitar) you don't need to make things complicated and just learn few shapes of chords and stick to them for a while. The whole point is to improve your hearing. You don't improve your voice separately to your hearing. In fact, if you couldn't hear your voice you couldn't sing a melody at all. The brain helps you guide your voice by listening to it.

Listening is the key to singing well, with a coach or without. Every kind of music is available online. so these steps could help you get where you want.1. Choose the kind of music you wish to sing. 2.Read a little about it, example: The best singers in the field, The best music composers of the kind of music you want to learn, basic structure of the music, and best songs in the genre. Okay! Now this may look tedious, but doesn’t really take more than an hour. 3. Download a lot of songs of the genre of different artists (Keeping in mind all the research you’ve done above). A lot means A LOT! 4. Start Listening to the songs. Listen to one song on a loop or keep shuffling, but make sure you listen to it, and just not hear it. Listen to the way the singer changes his/ her volume, mood, expressions. Listen thoroughly. 5. After you’ve understood the song and feel comfortable singing it. Keep Singing along with the song. This will help you compare yourself and evaluate where you’re going wrong. 6. Use your own mind. Copying someone is not the aim here, so, it is imperative for you to keep understanding and improvising. At first you will literally do no justice to the song, while improvising. But, this is important, this helps you understand what is it that sounded funny or what made your improvisation wrong. 7. Keep Singing…

EDIT: this has been merged, and most of the answer was targeted to original question details that got lost in the merge. I think you shouldn't label all the vocal teachers in whole Norway as no good based on one opinion of a friend. So really consider taking lessons. Remember that singing is very personal, so what works for your friend may not work for you and vice versa (given that the teaching is professional and based on healthy principles). Personal chemistry with the teacher certainly play a role. Some teachers are good at teaching the very basics to beginners and others are better at fine-tuning more advanced singers who already know the basics. What you can do on your own I suggest reading about voice and vocal technique. Find online sources, buy books or loan from library. The materials often include exercises that you can try and practice. Keep using your voice, sing and practice. Pay attention that you stay elastic and feel no tension or strain. Be your own teacher. Record your sessions and analyse what you like and what you could improve. Physical exercise that activates core muscles and uses breathing, like yoga or pilates, is useful. Better coordination in your body helps, because singing is a physical activity. What you can do online Some online "learn to sing" programs may be good, some are waste of money. Even if you pick a good one, you may misunderstand something, because there is nobody checking if you do the things right. For example there is often confusion between good body connection (what some call support) and pushing, and the latter can do damage. I think they may be more useful after some lessons when you already have some understanding and experience of the technical concepts. I recommend online lessons with a teacher as a second best option after live lessons. There are teachers who offer those. I have had Skype lessons with my teacher when either one was out of town/country and it worked ok. However, meeting a teacher live is still better. Especially for beginners it's sometimes easier to correct things when you can use your hands. Singing involves some core muscles you may not be so well aware of. Finding a right teacher You may need to try several teachers before you find the one that's right for you at your current phase. Some teachers offer the first trial lesson for a bit reduced price, so you can both see if it's a good match. If you don't notice any positive difference after a few lessons, it's time to move on. Don't fall for compliments, look for instruction HOW you improve something that needs work. A good teacher helps you to help yourself, so that you know what to work on when you do it on your own and how to practice. That is important if you can't take regular lessons.

Is it possible to sing without taking voice lessons? As far as I know, anyone can sing but the question is, how well? This guide can help you: The complete guide to singing like a professional There are different opportunities to learn how to sing well. You can observe famous singers in concerts, watch music videos in youtube or listen to recordings or read books. The complete guide to singing like a professional Transform Your Voice To A Professional Level! Maximize Your Vocal Range Get ready to gain an octave or more to your vocal range! Hit those high notes with full confidence and without strain or breaking. Our carefully developed system conditions your voice quickly and safely using professional grade techniques and advice. The complete guide to singing like a professional Rapidly Gain Vocal Strength & Agility Develop an effortless strength with your voice that will project a new confidence within your performances. Sing with power using only the most refined breakthrough singing methods that develop a vocal agility that lets you transition smoothly from different notes in the most precise way. The complete guide to singing like a professional Master Perfect Pitch The ability to train your ear and vocals for perfect pitch is one of the cornerstones of great singing. Our first class pitch perfecting software will not only hone your skills, but you will have fun doing it! The complete guide to singing like a professional

Do not listen to Greg, for some reason he is bitter (probably over his own singing misfortunes) and is just taking it out on you. Also his analogy is very poor considering there are no exams in order to officially be recognized as a singer by the state. Not to mention other things like required schooling. Seriously, it's a very bad analogy. Also, here is one of the most famous vocalists of our time at age 8 without any prior instruction: Christina Aguilera at 8 I know plenty of incredible singers who have never talked to a private instructor in their life. I, however, would not be where I am without instructors. But everybody is different. People like Greg are lucky to go anywhere with an instructor while others pick up the craft naturally. If you would like to improve the overall tonal quality of your voice, I would suggest picking songs you can sing and just recording yourself and trying new techniques (tongue position, width/height of mouth). A well-developed tone comes from time so just sing and be patient! (Seriously just sing with proper form for 2 hours a day every day and you'll see the improvement in no time). It took me a little over a year since age 17 before my tone started to become bareable. For breath support you can do things like blowing up balloons or blowing into your fist. You can also google excercises like exhaling in small bursts. Breathing Exercises If you have poor pitch and want to improve that then I'm afraid you'll need another person or an piece of equipment (I recommend the software Sing&See). Unfortunately, I don't know your age or what school you attend (if any), so I can't help you too much. If you have a way of joining a choir or acapella group I would definitely recommend that. Good luck!

There are indeed several ways to develop and be taught or learn to sing. I say this :humans have an impeccable ability to hear something is out of pitch or doesnt quite sound pleasing,now whether they can use this ability to train their own voice is where the actual challenge is. If you can talk you can sing. I am a performing recording musicia and i have acheived a professional singing voice without a coach. Heres what i did. I began to sing into a mini recorder while driving or anything where i was mostly alone. I would play the recordings back and say “whoa buddy i dont like what i hear’ so i began to dissect what i didnt like. I felt i should sing more in pitch so i sang into the recorder every day. One day i started to sing on pitch. Then i felt i needed to have more tone resonating thru me so i practiced singing the words to songs with longer periods of sound than speaking words. Then i didnt like my pronounciation so i tweaked words and sang them different ,then i learned how to vibrate my voice and to change the volume of my voice.. i did this almost every day for about 5 years.. i was already a drummer and keyboardist so i started singing in a band then anothet and then got asked to sing in 7 bands within a year. You can teach yourself. I also coach people how to sing Heres some of my music http://Http://www.reverbnation.com/winnterzkrossing Good luck!! Have fun!!

You are still quite young and, as you said yourself, your voice is still developing. Be gentle and patient with yourself and your voice while your voice changes or while you adapt to the changes, they are quite dramatic, right? As a young male I can't stress it more, keep exercising the falsetto (the high range that might sound weak and wimpy after your voice dropped). It is an integral part of your voice and must not be relegated to the unused shelf. You can do it by imitating an owl, a train whistle or your grandma calling, “"Yoo-hoo!” Or something more musical like descending arpeggios (broken chords) starting above the break and coming down. Aside from that, when singing, train your mind to focus on what you are doing, not how. The voice responds to stimuli given it by creating an environment for healthy phonation. Keep these things in mind while singing: pitch (the notes themselves - listen!)vowel (meaning. A, E, I, O, U and all the variations thereof) - is it clear? Is it the one you intended? Listen!Intensity (or volume level) - is it what is asked of you? Are you able to fluctuate easily from loud to soft and back or the other way around (Without pushing)?Musical pattern, or the phrase itself, how do you want to shape it? is it legato (Smooth and connected) or staccato (short, unconnected notes) or a combination? Where is the high point of the phrase etc.These are concepts that are formed before you start singing and held in your mind as you sing. The rest will work itself out and if you are musical and follow where your voice wants to lead you it won't lead you astray. Also, contrary to many, I would urge you not to waste much time on breathing exercises. The flow of air is regulated by the vocal chords themselves and not by the diaphragm or the core muscles As many would have you believe. The diaphragm reaction involuntarily land in direct correlation to the opening and closing of the glottis (the space between the vocal folds). We cannot overtly control it (and anyone who tries to tell you you can is full of - ah, well, they haven't studied anatomy enough). Our only hope on that front is to keep releasing the breath through and by refining our concepts. The best thing you can do is join a choir and sing a lot! Listening to great singers that have had quite a bit of longevity (meaning they sang into old age) and didn't lose their voices will help train your ear and mental concepts. Some recommendations: Pavarotti, Dietrich Fischer-Diskau, Nicolai Gedda, Jussi Björling. Good luck!

By singing! Just like any other instrument! Vocal coaches can do great things, and even if you only had a few lessons, it might be a good thing for you. Without such training, it’s possible to damage your voice by practicing wrong. But that’s not likely, if you’re not singing every day. Sing in the shower. Record yourself and listen back to critique yourself. Reach for high notes you have trouble reaching, then select songs that have parts you have to reach for, and sing them regularly, every day, until you have no problem hitting the higher notes. Rinse and repeat. Record yourself and critique yourself more! Record yourself at different volumes; use headphones; hear what your voice’s intricacies sound like at different volumes, and find your natural volume. Smile when you sing. There’s a world to learn about music and singing! Keep it fun! Original question: What is the best way to improve my singing voice without lessons?

The best way to improve singing without lessons is…PRACTICING AT HOME You don’t have to pay 50$ weekly for vocal lessons just to hear that you must practice more. You can practice all this stuff at home. You just need a computer or smartphone. You can find great stuff on the internet. Here some examples of things that you should practice. Breathing. Proper breathing equal good singing. While you are singing you should use your diaphragm. The diaphragm is an important muscle that helps you breathe in and out. If you want to train this muscle just lay on your back and breath. Laying on your back forces your diaphragm to work.Pitch training. First of all, you have to sing on a good pitch. To improve that skill you can play a scale on a piano and sing single notes. Don’t worry if you don’t have a piano, you can download a piano app on your mobile device. If you can’t play you can just press random keys and imitate sounds by your voice. That exercise will help you to always hit the right note while you are singing. Listen to yourself and ask yourself a question '' Am I sound right?'Warm up. You can do all that professional vocal warmups exercises like ‘’lip trills’’ or tongue trills. But you can sing a few of your favorite songs and it will warm you too. If you want to get more singing tips,you can use my FREE EBOOK ‘’How to sing better, useful singing tips’’

Do the scales for 15 mins a day at least. Their is lots of free tutorials kicking about, just do a web search and find one you are comfortable with. Warm up your vocal chords before launching into singing mode, ( this is very hard to follow, as I've never taken any notice of my own advice lol but it pays to warm the muscles up) Drink Water Drink Water Drink Water, cut and peel a bit of raw fresh ginger and add it to your water. Dont strain yourself dont strain your chords, as much as it is so tempting to do if your a crazy free style undisciplined freak like me, but dont do it if you have vocal work to do the next day. Be patient with yourself, listen to and sing the songs you love to sing, and suit your style, range, etc Listen to artist's that grab you, move you, not just the melody, but the lyrics too, this will help you find your own unique you. Watch the professionals and see how they breath, propell, exentuate, and hold their face. Try singing from your diaframe as oppose to your throat? I've never been able to master this but it dont mean you carnt. Good look have fun never give up and create your art.

The way children learn something - By doing it over and over again till you get it down pat.Kids also observe others doing the same thing and try to copy them.Take one song and practise it till you get it perfect or till really you hate singing that song whichever comes last.Do NOT sing falsetto. Sing the comfortable base notes first instead. This will help you relax and open up the vocal chords.Sing in museum range and top of base notes that are comfortable at first. Over time as you improve your range of base notes you'll find that it opens up your treble notes slowly too.Learn to relax your vocal chords ie swallowing muscles which get tightened when you sing with strain. This strains your vocal chords and give a squeaky feel to your singing esp in the higher notes.Learn to use your diaphragm to inhale and exhale. Consciously at first and then subconsciously as you continue your singing lessons.Practise sustained note singing with a wide open mouth, after slowly warming up your voice. This will help train both your vocal chords and ears to hit the right note on demand.Record what you sing and compare it with the original song. This is the feedback with which you’re going to train both your ears as well as your vocal cords.You'll find that some parts of the song come easy for you and others are tough.Be sure to give some rest to your voice and don't over-do or strain your voice esp if it pains or becomes hoarse.Do this for a few months. Change the song every 2 weeks and practise daily.Find songs which are in different ranges - bass, treble, mid-range. You'll find out very quickly what's your vocal range.Practise alone and perform when you're a bit comfortable with family, friends or well wishers.Listen 3 times more than you sing. If you train your ears, training your voice becomes that much easier.Hum-along with the song or hum without the song as much as you can.

When you want to become a better singer, most people will tell you to hire a vocal coach. All well and good, but what if you cannot find one you can work with, or you cannot afford one? Start off by perhaps learning an instrument like guitar or piano. If you can sing along with the guitar piano while you play, it shows that you are in tune which is one of the hardest parts of improving your singing alone. You should practice with the age-old classic, Do Re Me, from The Sound of Music. It’s great for practicing scales, which is one of the main things a vocal coach would work with you on; master Do Re Mi, though, and you are on the right path to stardom. Record yourself; a vocal coach is merely giving you feedback, so record yourself on a good laptop mic or phone mic and listen back. You might shock yourself at your progress! Practice, though, is your best part. A typical vocal coach would have you for 30mins-2 hours every day, so for aim for around 45mins-1hr every day of ‘’training’ – the more you exercise and strengthen those vocal chords, the better you’ll be. Read More: Learn To Sing Tips

One of the most important things you can do is to practice things like scales and arpeggios as well as other vocal exercises and techniques such as vibrato and melisma. Although things like scales and arpeggios can be tedious and boring (trust me, I know!), they help tune your musical ear so when you sing actual songs, you are able to hit the notes much more accurately. When practicing for my music exams, the last thing I wanted to do was practice my scales. I just wanted to play the pieces as they were much more enjoyable. But the scales helped me learn different finger patterns that would make the pieces easier to play and sound much more fluid. I understand singing does not require as much coordination but the ability to jump between notes and make it sound pleasant is a hard skill to master whether it be played on an instrument or on your vocal chords. As with any musical techniques, you should start slowly and gradually increase the tempo, making sure to prioritise accuracy over speed to get the technique down. From here, you can start doing variations on the rhythm to better simulate singing a piece of music. For example, a normal scale would be written quaver, quaver, quaver, quaver. You can instead sing: quaver, crotchet, quaver, crotchet or quaver, crotchet, minim, crotchet, quaver, what ever you can come up with. These exercises will gradally improve your vocal ability so singing harder, more technical pieces will become easier and sound better.

Gone are those days when you have to go for lessons to learn anything new. The world has gone so advanced now that you can easily learn anything you want; you just have to know the right way to do so. It might be possible that you might need a mentor who can guide you the right path but that doesn’t mean you have to go for any lessons. The same is with the idea of improving your singing. You might be good with your voice but then you want to improve it. The good part is, you can do this without the need for vocal lessons. Here are some of the effective ways through which you can observe improvement in your singing: Vocal tutorials on YouTube: The trend has gone digital, so the people too. People these days have got everything they want to see and learn on the videos on YouTube. Even if you want to work on your singing skills, YouTube can help you with that too. Start watching the tutorials based on the singing lessons and you can learn a lot from it and work on your singing skills.Listen to music with earphones on and singing: This is quite a common way to work on your singing, and it’s simple too. You just play any song you know on your mobile phone and plug in the earphones to listen to it. Sing along with the song. The more you keep on practicing like this, the more you’ll go towards the improvement.Sing in front of your friends and family and ask for honest reviews: Sometimes our friends and family can be the best mentor and critic. Sing in front of them and ask them for their honest reviews. Focus on what they point out as your loopholes and start working on it.These are a few effective ways through which you can continue to improve your singing skills, without even spending for the vocal lessons. But for quick and better results, it is always recommended to take the help and supervision of the professionals.

Thanks for the A2A. Straight to the point, I do not recommend you to do that. I know this might not answer your question, but truthfully learning by yourself is often not the way to go because you might not realize that you are developing bad habits that seem trivial but actually affect your singing. These habits include, but not limited to (since I have these bad habits and at times they still come that I have to consciously tell myself to not do them) poor posture, excessive nasality, singing breathy when going soft, shallow breathing, and others. If you have a good vocal coach, you can immediately correct these habits when he or she spots them while you are singing.  At the same time, do not just believe your friend who told you that vocal coaches in your country are not good. You cannot decide that if you have not tried one for yourself. Besides, your singing goals might be different from your friend's anyway - she just might not find the one that she is looking for.

Here is a simple way that will cost you maybe 200 - 300 dollars. Buy - a large diaphragm microphone, a small mixer with effects built in, isolating headphones (cadh100 $50 or something from vic firth), maybe a Mic stand and digital recorder if you phone doesn't record. You can get these used if on a tight budget. Then sing karaoke off YouTube and record it. Really, if you are honest and not tone deaf, listen to your recordings and see what you are doing wrong. Singing is like anything repetitive, If you do it often enough and are self critical, you will get better. Sing every day or every other day to start and you will see improvement. Karaoke helps because you know what it's supposed to sound like. You may hate your voice. Listen, most people do. Being used to yourself often will give you the confidence to sing. That confidence is 80% of singing well, without it you will sound boxed in and afraid. Be free to let your talent and emotions out of your mouth! Good luck.

This is the reply for those: {Who do not want to attend any special type of vocals and music classes {Who want to learn on their own sitting at their home only without paying a single penny to a vocal coach. {Who have got real talent in singing or has passion towards singing or want to make their carrier in Singing. It is the question that is among all the beginners in this field. Speaking from my personal learning experience about learning singing or to improve singing skills is just simple and not too hard. First and foremost, You select some songs (which are your favourite and very much good to practice) and add them into your newly created playlist. Note that you don’t select too many songs at once, otherwise you would get confused and will not be able to concentrate on one. Only 3 to 4 songs would be perfect. Secondly, divide each song on the basis of months or weeks, which means that during whole week or whole month you will practice only that selected song. Now the actual thing comes: What you need to do is listen to that song (from starting till end) and sing along with that song. After that you will came to know that which part you can easily sing and which you struggle the most or just cannot sing that part. Try to adapt the originality like that of the playback singer used in original song. And if you are creative minded then you will develop or modify the song by your own. This will improve your vocal and singing skills drastically. But, remember one thing: “Practice is the key to success for anything upon this world and to become perfectionist.” . . Now I shall share my own experience about this topic. I used to sing a particular song which was my favourite in back 2011-’12 repeatedly and discover new things in a similar song many a times. And after few months I mastered in that song and then began to sing different style of songs which I liked and kept those classical style songs away because I didn’t liked it at all. I came to know what kind of songs I can sing easily and with creativeness in it and eliminate those kind of songs which I disliked from the start. Find the uniqueness in the same song which only you can create on this world and no one else can do by their own. Hope all the readers who want to be a good vocalist gets appropriate solution :)

Hello. You can't. Even without “formal lessons” with a teacher, by singing along to other songs, or trying to copy another singers voice, you ARE still learning. BUT, what you hear in songs is rarely what came out of their mouth. Instruction from a qualified vocal teacher will help you understand what the singer is actually doing physically. Where to start. Buy a book on singing - I recommend Mark Baxter's book “Rock n Roll Singers Survival Guide” . It says “Rock n Roll” in the title but the book is very general to fit any genre of singing. It's a great book on singing using plain language and a little humor. There are also many vocal courses out there that slow you to have lessons at your own pace and in the privacy of your own home. Here's a link to my beginners vocal course that doubles for a warm up routine: Singers & Speakers Course There are others out there from Robert Lunte, Ken Tamplin, Brett Manning but expect to pay way over $100 for them. Mine costs US $35.00. Kevin Richards Singing Lessons Worldwide - RPM Vocal Studios NYC, Kevin Richards

It’s always been a personal belief of mine that anyone can sing. Anyone at all, as long as they work hard enough for it. If you were not born with the natural talent of being on pitch, you just have to work hard at it. It’s best if you have a tuned piano. Use the piano to familiarize yourself with the tones and try emulating famous nursery rhymes from memory. There are also online pianos if you don’t own a real piano. Once you’ve worked long enough on it, you can move on to singing a song. Don’t think about technique first. Just make sure you get the pitch right. Choose an easy pop song, like Baby, one that doesn’t have a ton of riffs, high notes, or low notes. Then move on to a little more challenging songs. Call Me Maybe is a step up. Make sure you got every note right. After you do simple pop songs, you can try your hand at developing technique by reading 5 Tips on How to Improve Your Singing Voice. Then you can try your hand at more complicated songs.

Sing constantly, but make sure you aren't hurting your voice, don't strain. Honestly though you need to take lessons from somebody, youtube and online help can only do so much.  the only things you can do that wont hurt you voice is:1. Sing constantly, but don't strain2. teach yourself music theory3. Sing scales, learn all the modes, not just the classical ones.4. Memorize songs, sing them with and without the tracks, turn the track on at the beginning and at the end to see if your'e still in the same key. 5. Learn some classical pieces, these help you develop a rich tone and well rounded voice.  there is a lot of youtube videos that will tell you basically the same thing, but with some more specifics. EricArceneaux this guy is probably the best one on youtube.

I can't say that I've never attended any singing lessons but that was just one half an hour beginner class so I'm not sure if that would count.Well I'm quite into musicals so I would pick some favorite musical songs and listen repeatedly until I can sing the complete song correctly-I mean knowing exactly where to pause where to breathe and how to convey the emotions.It was basically just imitation but gradually your voice would become similar to the singer you imitated after a long time of daily practices.But not really practice if you're not in a hurry,just sing something while bored at home,make it a habit. Oh and it would be better if you occasionally record your own voice to mortify your singing.

Someone on the Marc Maron "WTF" podcast said, "just sing along with Elvis Costello."  Seriously.  Haven't tried it, but I think copying artists with a similar voice to yours may be helpful.   However, I'd say you should be careful to warm up your voice and make an effort to gradually build up your range. Of course, you listen to someone like Dire Strait's Mark Knopfler and he just stays in a very narrow range and writes songs to suit his voice effortlessly. He also plays kick-ass guitar.  That always helps.

You can improve your singing by this pattern LISTEN-SING-RECORD-LISTEN 1- First you have to listen and origional song. When you are familier to that song then your mind automatically generate the wibes to sing. 2- Practice singing in a empty room or in bathroom. 3- then once you get good vibrations then record it in your cell phone. 4- then after sometime listen that recording and take feed back from your friends also. 5- dont be nurvouse it takes time but you will be perfect by practicing.  this is my video recording.

Choir. Most academic choirs, community choirs, and some church choirs have professional directors that know techniques to help you sing and you aren’t required to audition. Yes, singing in a choir would be different that singing a solo, but it is a start. Also, in a volunteer choir you won’t be put down for not having perfect technique. A lot of community choruses have music teachers in them. They can give you advice during the breaks. Look them up online. I bet there are DVDs, CDs, and books that go with them that you can purchase. I would record your voice as you critique your own voice during the process. Listen to other singers in the style you like. Try to sing with those recordings.

This may sound simple, but may I suggest that you learn lyrics off by heart very confidently, preferably in several languages. You will be surprised at how much more fluidly you will sing when you know the words, their meaning and put ‘sentences’ and ‘articulation’ into your performances. Sing every day, not necessarily at full voice and record yourself and be your own true critic. Look at improvement, not damning yourself for errors. Make it fun. Get physically fit with an accent on good posture and breathing techniques (swimming can help). Enjoy the process !

Sing... Sing along to songs you know. If you drive, keep CDs in the car... If you choose a handful of songs and stick with them, your voice will improve. It's knowing the songs that does the trick. Keep at it and don't give up. When you are ready, go to a karaoke, there are loads where people just sing for pleasure. You are unlikely to be the worst singer there, and if you are, no one will be bothered. They will just be secretly pleased that you have saved them the worry that they will be the worst. If you really don't want to perform, just keep singing on your own. It's fun. Enjoy the freedom. Sing like there's nobody listening as they say.

I totally agree with Marja Kari :) You’ve got a lot of time to improve your voice and based on the info you’ve provided your voice should still be on the infancy level (maturity wise). It’s a long read dear and you’re gonna notice a lot of changes in your voice. However, if you treat your voice wrong right now then those changes can turn out to be drastic too. Therefore, focusing on its right training should be your choice if you probably want to develop a career in singing in the future. Now, you may not be able to take singing lessons right now whatever the reason may be but let me get this straight, if you are working with a well knowledgeable and educated teacher how has a proven track record and can actually help you out in singing then my friend there’s no better option you can shoot for. Till the time you find out that opportunity you can take your time to check out some articles over the web and videos on Youtube. There’s a tone of useful stuff out there and stay assured you won’t regret spending time here. You can take a look at this video to get started:

Are you a member of a church choir or community chorus? You could get some free (or at least really cheap) basic help from the director - almost every local director of that type of group has a degree in music. Of course, daily practice is also important, along with understanding your true range and the vocal style that fits your voice. Some voices fit better in a choir/ensemble, others as soloists, but even then some voices are better suited for pop, rock, opera, operetta, Broadway, etc. It’s the rare bird that does really well across genres.

I guess I’d say, “only listen to singers who have good, healthy, safe technique.” At least that way you’re filling your ear with good vocal models to emulate (and, in truth, that’s really how we all learn to sing at least rudimentarily). But nothing replaces a real, live person for working out the finer details. Let me be this blunt: a refusal to take a voice teacher or coach is a commitment to never being an excellent singer, and probably to never having any reasonably successful singing career. Even the “screamers” have voice teachers (but don’t ask me what they’re teaching, I have no idea).

If you try to learn vocal technique without a teacher, 2 things will happen: You will listen to the sounds of your voice in your head to try to give you feedback, which doesn’t make use of your sinus cavity or approach, and will greatly harm the quality of your sound.You will be like my coworker who plays the guitar by looking up fingerings on the web, but doesn’t even know what chord he’s playing, which to the musical world, is laughable, and not in the least bit a legitimate musician.

If you don’t want or cannot afford singing lessons. You’re gonna have to do the job yourself as in “listen a LOT, practice a LOT and learn by yourself a LOT”. There is no guaranty you’re going to get any results but you may improve! You may also take bad singing habits or injure yourself so pay attention to what you feel and stop as soon as it hurts (you should not experience any pain). Good luck and take lessons once you can ;-) -Vahnvocal coach

I’ll tell you how I got better, granted I had an early musical education and I read music and then helps a lot. If you haven’t already done so join a good chorus. I don’t know how you can tell if the chorus is good or not, but the director should be giving vocal tips and techniques as she or he directs the chorus in rehearsal. Pay attention to everything that person says and try to practice it on your own at home. Another way to improve is to keep noodling around with your voice at home. Don’t stretch it, just do some simple low range exercises till your throat feels warmed up. Don’t push the top. You can also get actual inexpensive lessons by calling up the music department of your local university. Lots of grad students give lessons.

All people say that without vocal teacher one can’t be better than with vocal teacher but here’s the thing. I often hear a traditional song sings by native, they sing really good and surely don’t have vocal coach in their village. I can say that there is still a chance that someone can sing really good without vocal teacher.

There is a whole wealth of free singing tutorials on Youtube. They are everywhere and the choice of learning material is vast. Start there by doing a simple search. In the meantime, look for any opportunity in your comfort zone…. school choir, karaoke etc. My favorite was community theatre. Your local paper may have information for auditions. I always liked doing community theatre because I would work with adults who were far more experienced then I was. The more you do it, the better you will get. Best of luck!

There are many people who improve their singing skills without taking singing lessons, but I recommend that taking singing lessons would improve your singing talent much more as compared to improving it without. Many techniques are involved in good singing, so if you have some guidance it would certainly be beneficial for you.

Start with some youtube tutorials on singing techniques and best practices. There are many videos for vocal exercises that help in improving and maintaining voice and building singing stamina. You might have to alter your eating and drinking habits to take better care of and preserve your voice. Practice singing regularly (daily if possible). You should see substantial results with these steps. Once you have improved and want to take your singing to next (super professional) level then you should consider taking professional coaching. Ground work can always start at home without spending much money. Getting some tips from professional singers is also a great way of learning but bear in mind, what worked for one may not work for another.

A good way to improve your singing is to do warm ups. you can sing the c scale up and down, and remember to make it fun. Another way is to make sure your not to breathy when you sing so you can breathe in an hold for 5 counts and then see how long you can hold that know when you breathe out. How this helps.

Find YouTube videos with scales / breathing exercises and tipsUse tuning appsyou’ll need to understand and develop three different crucial areas a) breathing b) contact c) shapingrecord yourself practising on your phone - you then listen and give yourself feedbackpush yourself outside of comfort zones so head out to sing at open mics - give yourself goals

The question is inappropriate. It seems like how i ll get educated without getting into school/colleges. Well you might learn an average things without taking vocal lessons,but to become Mr. Perfect you have to go into the depth of relevant subject i.e. you should take some lessons from well known professionals.

Record yourself (be prepared for a shock - what you hear is not what other people hear), and practice, changing the way you place your voice until you like what you hear on the recording. You don’t need to know what your vocal range is to do this. Sing what feels comfortable, and what you enjoy.

There are plenty of great online vocal courses out there which actually works wonders. Effectively they are much cheaper than having a live vocal coach. I strongly suggest one should use these courses as I have personally learnt singing the same way. There is a video I know which did a review of the “best singing courses” out there. It personally helped me. You should check it out.

Well, if you’re sure you have a firm handle on healthy vocal technique, it is certainly possible to improve your singing voice without professional guidance. But if not, to be on the safe side, it’s well worth at least a few lessons with a qualified vocal coach to get you started on the right path.
Very difficult to do without a good voice teacher. Unless you are naturally gifted and some people are. But most need guidance to learn the fundamentals of proper breath support.

There are the “self-help” tapes (some of them are really good), videos, you can join a chorus or choir, or even record yourself singing which will allow you to hear how you sound and give you some ideas on where you need work. However, the best methods (in my opinion) are joining a choir or chorus because you have an instructor to help you right there and it doesn’t cost anything.

Well you will need a live person to hear you with the education, knowledge & experience to advise you properly. No app for that! You can always do live online lessons which might be a cheaper way to go, if finding the right person in your area is difficult. But check them out thoroughly first. Good luck!

There isn’t one. Hard work, with a qualified and solid instructor who knows your voice and helps you through the breathing & development necessary over MANY years, will help you with that. But, your range is finite, and it is a function of your mouth cavity, breath capacity, and your vocal folds effective resonance. Getting a “Rolf” massage can help increase your bodies relaxation which helps these other attributes, but in all honesty, there’s no substitute for hard work with a good instructor.

Just sing. You don't need lessons right now unless you have a full performing schedule and need to make sure not to strain your voice. Just sing. Also learn to play an instrument so your music-reading will get good.
Your question is like how do I get buffed without going to the gym, or how can I never feel hungry without eating, or how i learn to swim without getting in the water. My Advice “TURN ON THAT BRAIN”

I am creating a singing blog where I give out free singing resources as well as do course reviews. I just started a series called “Foundation is Key” which is the most important part in singing. https://singingempire.com

If you really want to learn singing then you have to do vocal exercise like we do gym everyday. Vocal exercise are omkar, sargam, alankar, raag and khayal of raag. If you do these exercise at home no one can train and analyze your mistake during riyaz and you may do mistake in daily practice. So, my opinion is that you should go for vocal lesson from a classical singer.

well, I taught myself with my favorite songs. For power and abdominal breathing, I sing Clutch songs. I also do breathing exercises with a 20 pound weight on my abdomen. For range I sing Queen or Fun. For pitch quality I sing P!ATD and Darius Rucker. be careful to watch singers in music videos, it shows you stance and what to relax when singing.
You may try singing to karaoke on YouTube; Singing Buddy or KaraFun can be good; for warm-ups try something like this:
You should try and sing as if you are YAWNING all the time. Do not keep your tonque flat.
